* Network optimization: Shortest path, maximum flow, minimum cost flow, assignment problem, transportation problem, network simplex method.

MTH351.title: STATISTICS II
MTH351.description: Probability distributions of functions of random variables, the law of large numbers and the central limit theorem. Point and interval estimation, optimal estimation, maximum likelihood methods, more on tests of hypotheses, Neyman-Pearson lemma, likelihood ratio tests, large sample theory, Chi-square tests and contingency tables.

MTH353.title: DATA ANALYSIS WITH COMPUTER
MTH353.description: This course introduces the use of software for performing statistical data analysis. The topics concentrate on the use of statistical computer packages with main focus on SAS and we will also introduce SPSS and Splus/R. Data analysis process and collecting data, graphical and numerical methods for describing data, summarizing bivariate data, probability and population distribution, estimation and hypothesis testing using a single sample, comparing two population or treatments,analysis of categorical data and goodness-of-fit tests.

MTH361.title: MATHEMATICAL FOUNDATIONS OF GAME THEORY
MTH361.description:
Games of normal form and extensive form, applications in economics, relations between game theory and decision making.

Games of complete information: static games with finite or infinite strategy spaces, Nash equilibrium of pure and mixed strategy, dynamic games, backward induction solutions, information sets, subgame-perfect equilibrium, finitely and infinitely repeated games.

Games of incomplete information: Bayesian equilibrium, first price sealed auction, second price sealed auction, and other auctions, dynamic Bayesian games, perfect Bayesian equilibrium, signaling games.

Cooperative games: bargaining theory, cores of n-person cooperative games, the Shapley value and its applications in voting, cost sharing, etc.

MTH411.title: REAL ANALYSIS II
MTH411.description: Riemann integral, integrability, fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integrals. Equicontinuous family of functions, Stone-Weierstrass Theorem. Fourier series. Introduction to metric spaces, the normed space Rn, and in the context of metric spaces the notions of limits, continuity, balls, neighbourhoods, open and closed sets, completeness, compactness, Heine-Borel Theorem, connectedness, space of continuous functions, contraction mapping principle. The Arzela-Ascoli Theorem, Weierstrass Approximation Theorem, the Inverse Function Theorem in Rn, the Implicit Function Theorem in Rn.

MTH412.title: ALGEBRAIC TOPOLOGY
MTH412.description: Review of point-set topology. Homotopy. CW- or simplicial complexes. Fundamental group. Homology groups.

MTH416.title: PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
MTH416.description:
The objective of this introductory course on partial differential equations is to provide their basic properties as well as the techniques to solve some such equations. 
* First-order equations, Quasi-linear equations, general first-order equation for a function of two variables, Cauchy problem
* Wave equation, wave equation in two independent variables, Cauchy problem for hyperbolic equations in two independent variables
* Heat equation, the weak maximum principle for parabolic equations, Cauchy problem for heat equation, regularity of solutions to heat equation. 
* Laplace equation, Green's formulas, harmonic functions, maximum principle for Laplace equation, Dirichlet problem, Green's function and Poisson's formula

MTH426.title: CODING THEORY
MTH426.description:
This course is to introduce basic notions in the theory of error-correcting codes which is used in data storage and telecommunication. 
* Error detection, correction and decoding, Hamming distance
* Basic facts on finite fields
* Linear codes, Hamming weight, generator and parity-check matrices, encoding, decoding.
* Bounds, Hamming codes, Golay codes, perfect codes, MDS codes
* Construction of codes, Reed-Muller codes.
* Cyclic codes, generator polynomials, BCH codes, Reed-Solomon codes
* Computer implementation of efficient coding and decoding.

MTH428.title: TOPICS IN MATHEMATICS OF INFORMATION AND COMMUNICATION
MTH428.description: The choice of the topics depends on the instructor.

MTH436.title: MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING
MTH436.description: Unconstrained optimization: one-dimensional search, gradient method, Newton-Raphson method. Constrained optimization: feasible direction methods, penalty/barrier function methods, modern interior point methods for convex programming. Discrete optimization: formulations, cutting plane methods, branch-and-bound methods, Lagrangian relaxation, dynamic programming approach.

MTH451.title: TIME SERIES ANALYSIS
MTH451.description:
This course introduces time series models used in economics, engineering and finance. 
* Trend fitting, autoregressive and moving average models, spectral analysis
* Seasonality, forecasting and estimation
* Use of computer package to analyze real data sets

MTH452.title: MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS
MTH452.description: Distribution theory: multivariate normal distribution, Hotelling's T2 and Wishart distributions, inference on the mean and covariance, principal components and canonical correlation, factor analysis, discrimination and classification.

PAP212.title: ELECTROMAGNETISM
PAP212.description: This course introduces key concepts in electromagnetism. Electric dipole moment, polarization and displacement, multipole expansion. Laplace's and Poisson's equations; uniqueness theorem; method of images, electrostatic energy. Magnetic dipole moment, magnetic field and flux, magnetic scalar and vetctor potentials; magnetization and magnetic media, permeability and susceptibility; properties of B and H; boundary conditions. Equation of continuity, Maxwell equations and relativistic invariance; Electromagnetic wave equation, electromagnetic spectrum, magnetic and electric energy densities, Poynting flux, momentum flux, radiation pressure, polarization.

PAP219.title: PHYSICS LAB IIB
PAP219.description: This course will train students in experimental physics covering a wide variety of topics: Electromagnetism, thermal physics, solid state and materials physics.

PAP231.title: PHYSICAL OPTICS
PAP231.description: This course aims to establish the basic principles of physical optics which form the foundation for many modern sciences and technologies. Wave properties, refraction and dispersion, interference, Michelson interferometer, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, resolution limit, Fourier transformation, holography; polarization, birefringence and wave plates, Fabry-Perot etalons, optical coatings, zone plates.

PAP261.title: INTRODUCTION TO LASERS
PAP261.description:
This course serves as an introduction to lasers and their working principles.
Quantum transitions in atoms, stimulated emission and amplification, rate equations, saturation, feedback, coherent optical oscillation, laser resonators, and various types of lasers.

PAP321.title: STATISTICAL MECHANICS I
PAP321.description:
This course introduces the postulates and key ideas in statistical mechanics, with applications to classical and quantal gases.

* Basic postulates, macrostates and microstates, distinguishable and indistinguishable particles, distribution functions
* Temperature, entropy and the probability of system configuration occurring, Boltzmann relation, canonical ensemble and partition function
* Gibb's entropy; Third law of thermodynamics; information theory; irreversible processes and arrow of time
* Density of states; heat capacity in black body radiation
* Ideal classical gas, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution, rotational and vibrational heat
* Free electron gas, Fermi energy and distribution function, Pauli paramagnetism
* Electronic contribution to heat capacity
* Phonons as normal modes, contribution to heat capacity, Debye approximation; phonon gas, thermal conductivity of insulators
* Mean description of phase transitions - Weiss model of ferromagnetism, order-disorder transition

PAP339.title: PHYSICS LAB IIIB
PAP339.description: This course provides students in the Applied Physics Track with further advanced training in experimental physics covering a wide variety of topics: semiconductor physics, photonics, biophysics, and thin film growth.

PAP341.title: ATOMIC PHYSICS
PAP341.description:
This course discusses the origins of atomic spectra and shows the application of quantum mechanics in describing the interaction between electron and nuclei in atoms.

* Hydrogen atom - central potential approximation, radial wavefunction, quantum numbers, energy levels and degeneracy; electron spin and total angular momentum; spin-orbit coupling and fine structure; Zeeman splitting
* Helium atom - Coulomb repulsion and exchange; singlet-triplet splitting
* Electronic configuration and periodic table; alkali metals; residual electrostatic interaction; LS-coupling scheme; Hund's rules; hyperfine structure and isotope shift
* Selection rules for electric dipole interaction
* Zeeman and Stark effects
* Inner shell transitions and x-ray spectra
* Doppler broadening in laser spectroscopy.

PAP342.title: SOLID STATE PHYSICS I
PAP342.description:
This course discusses the electronic and magnetic properties of solids.

* Metals - conductivity and heat capacity; density of states at Fermi level; nearly free electron model and band gaps
* Distinction between metals, semiconductors, and insulators
* Semiconductors - direct and indirect band gap (Si, Ge, GeAS); optical absorption, effective mass and holes; carrier concentration, law of mass action; impurity donors and acceptors; mobility and Hall effect; band gap measurements
* Magnetic susceptibility, Larmor diamagnetism, paramagnetism, and Curie's law; Pauli paramagnetism; magnetic ordering (ferromagnetism and anti-ferromagnetism) and Weiss molecular field theory; Curie-Weiss susceptibility

PAP352.title: CHAOTIC DYNAMICAL SYSTEMS
PAP352.description:
This course introduces the ideas of determinism and randomness in the physical world.

* Introduction to phase plane, critical points and characterization (hyperbolic/elliptic) - free and damped oscillators, prey-predator models
* Simple extensions to three-dimensional phase space and beyond, e.g. rotation of rigid bodis, the Lorenz system
* Integrable and non-integrable systems, Poincare return maps
* Discrete dynamics - 1D and 2D maps; fixed points and stability; period doubling - shift map, logistic map
* Breakdown of order and chaos; sensitivity to initial conditions ("butterfly effect") and Lyapunov exponents; limit to predictability; strange attractors and fractal dimension - Kepler problem, Henon-Heiles system
* Stable and unstable manifolds, homoclinic and heteroclinic tangle, lobes and turnstile transport, particle motion in 2D incompressible fluid

PAP441.title: QUANTUM MECHANICS III
PAP441.description:
This course discusses quantum interactions between matter and electromagnetic fields.
Time-independent perturbation theory - non-degenerate and degenerate. Variational method, ground state energy and eigenfunction. Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
Hamiltonian in an electromagnetic field, vector potential, phase and Aharanov-Bohm effect. Dirac equation, spin, gyromagnetic ratio and antiparticles. Zeeman and Landau levels.
Transitions - two-state system, Rabi oscillations, Larmor precession, magnetic resonance; time-dependent perturbation theory, Fermi's golden rule, scattering and Born approximation; radiative transition transitions; electric dipole approximation, quantised electromagnetic field.
Quantum information - quantum cryptography, entanglement and teleportation; quantum computing.

PAP444.title: NANOSCALE PHYSICS
PAP444.description: This course introduces the physical and transport properties in nanoscale systems.Electron gas in 2D and multilayer systems. Quantum transport in 1D; magnetotunneling; quantum capacitance and conductance.Quantum dots and artificial atoms; eigenenergies and eigenstates; single particle conductance; Coulomb blockade; Kondo effect; Aharanov-Bohm effect.Quantum computation - electrons and quasi-electrons as qubits; state preparation, manipulation, entanglement and measurement; Rabi oscillations and single-spin detection.Some methods for quantum dot and nanostructure growth will be discussed.

PAP446.title: ECONOPHYSICS
PAP446.description: This course introduces statistical physics-inspired approaches to economics and finance.  Review basic concepts in probability and statistics.  Low- and high-frequency data in economics and finance.  Gaussian and fat-tailed return distributions.  Autocorrelation, memory, and nonstationarity in time series data.  Cross correlations in financial markets.  Random matrix theory.  Correlation filtering and minimal spanning trees.  Time series clustering.  Agent-based models of financial markets.  Stylized facts from simulation results.

PAP449.title: QUANTUM ELECTRONICS
PAP449.description:
This course aims to provide students with a solid foundation of photonics and optical technology.
Classical linear and nonlinear optics, photons and quantum optics, statistical optics, semiclassical and quantum models on interaction between light and matter, lasers, generation of short laser pulses.

PAP455.title: COMPUTATIONAL PHYSICS
PAP455.description:
This course introduces computational methods and tools to solving physical problems.
Introduction to computational methods and tools. Programming Concepts.  Errors and Uncertainties in Computations; Numerical solutions of differential equations in one variable.  Approximation of functions. Variational Principle and Minimization ; spectral analysis,   Monte Carlo simulations, Symbolic computing;   High-performance computing. Applications to physical problems,  molecular dynamics. Electronic structure of atoms, Hartree-Fock approximation and Density Functional Theory. Maxwell's Equations in Matter and ionized gases. Physics with MAPLE/MATLAB.

PAP457.title: TOPICS IN PHYSICS
PAP457.description: This course introduces students to topics in Physics which are at the frontier of theoretical physics. Topics are chosen from various areas of theoretical physics, such as general relativity, quantum field theory, elementary particle physics, quantum chromodynamics, astrophysics, cosmology, string theory, condensed matter physics etc. Students will be informed of the topic selected before the start of the semester.

PAP461.title: SEMICONDUCTOR & DEVICE PHYSICS
PAP461.description:
This course aims to introduce solid state devices that signify modern technologies and Hi-Tech industries.
Electronic band structures of semiconductors, electronic properties of defects, charge carrier concentrations, drift of carriers in electric and magnetic fields, diffusion and recombination of excess carriers, p-n junction physics, junction diodes, tunnel diodes, photodiodes, light emitting diodes, bipolar junction transistors, junction field effect transistors (JFET), metal-semiconductor contacts metal-insulator-semiconductor interfaces, basic MOSFET.

PAP463.title: SOFT CONDENSED MATTER PHYSICS
PAP463.description:
This course provides an introduction to soft-condensed matter physics.
Atomic and molecular forces. Hard-core repulsion. Polymers. Elasticity of DNA. Correlations in the fluctuations of solvent molecules; diffusion in fluids, electrostatics in solution. Poisson-Boltzmann theory. Electrophoresis; liquid interfaces and droplets.   Lipid bilayers and vesicles.; membrane fluctuations, cell mechanics; Colloids. Liquid crystal phases. Random aggregation and fractals; hydrodynamics of an isotropic fluid: the Navier-Stokes equation. The Reynolds number; laminar flow. Viscoelasticity; Experimental methods - dynamic light scattering, self-assembling processes, fluorescence correlation spectroscopy, measuring interactions with laser tweezers and tracking experiments.

PAP465.title: MEDICAL PHYSICS FOR RADIOTHERAPY
PAP465.description: This course will introduce the fundamental and clinical aspects of radiation physics, dosimetry concepts and techniques, dose calculation methods and treatment planning, radiobiology and radiation safety for Radiotherapy.

PH1011.title: PHYSICS
PH1011.description:
1. VECTORS
2. KINEMATICS
3. FORCES AND TORQUES
4. NEWTON?S LAWS OF MOTION
5. IMPULSE AND MOMENTUM
6. WORK AND ENERGY
7. THERMAL PHYSICS
8. ELECTRIC FIELD
9. MAGNETIC FIELD
10. MOTION OF CHARGED PARTICLES AND APPLICATIONS
11. CIRCUITS
programmes: Electrical & Electronic Engineering And Economics Year 1
Information Engineering & Media And Economics Year 1

PH1102.title: FIELDS AND OSCILLATIONS
PH1102.description: This course introduces basic notions of fields and oscillatory behaviour. Simple harmonic motion - time-dependence, angular frequency and phase; mass on a spring, relative phases; coupled oscillations and normal modes; phasor diagrams; representations in complex plane; damped oscillations and energy decay. Electromagnetic fields - Coulomb's law, electric field & potential; Gauss' law and capacitance; moving charges, magnetic flux density and Ampere's law; flux in circuits, Faraday's law and magnetostatic energy; JJ Thompson's experiment. Electrical circuits - voltage, current and resistance; Kirchoff's laws; exponential decay in circuits. Oscillations in circuits - LC circuits and relative phases; complex current and voltage; complex impedance; electrical resonance; filter and bandwidth; mechanical impedance.

PH1103.title: OPTICS AND WAVES
PH1103.description:
This course studies the behaviour and properties of optical and particle waves. 
Waves, interference and optics - waves on a string, 1-D wave equation and solution; 3-D running waves and wave-vector; superposition; electromagnetic waves; phase and group velocity, boundary conditions, reflection and transmission coefficients, refractive index, Brewster angle, wave attenuation; Huygen?s principle, Young?s slits and diffraction grating; reflection and refraction; lens formulae; real and virtual images; telescope.
Wave-particle duality - photoelectric effect; photons, energy and momentum; Compton scattering; de Broglie waves.

PH1199.title: PHYSICS LABORATORY IB
PH1199.description: This course will train students in basic experimental physics that include topics in electricity & magnetism, circuits, optics and wave phenomena. The laboratory sessions are designed to provide an active learning experience where key concepts can be better appreciated.

PH1802.title: FOUNDATIONS OF PHYSICS II
PH1802.description: Foundations of physics covering (a) electricity and magnetism, (b) optics, and (c) modern physics, with examples of practical applications to biomedical sciences, engineering sciences and other fields. Students learn about the principles of the physical world from which scientific and engineering applications are built upon. At a general level, students learn how to read scientific material effectively, identify fundamental concepts, reason through scientific questions, and solve quantitative problems.

PH2102.title: ELECTROMAGNETISM
PH2102.description: This course introduces key concepts in electromagnetism. Electric dipole moment, polarization and displacement, multipole expansion. Laplace's and Poisson's equations; uniqueness theorem; method of images, electrostatic energy. Magnetic dipole moment, magnetic field and flux, magnetic scalar and vetctor potentials; magnetization and magnetic media, permeability and susceptibility; properties of B and H; boundary conditions. Equation of continuity, Maxwell equations and relativistic invariance; Electromagnetic wave equation, electromagnetic spectrum, magnetic and electric energy densities, Poynting flux, momentum flux, radiation pressure, polarization.

PH2199.title: PHYSICS LAB IIB
PH2199.description: This course will train students in experimental physics covering a wide variety of topics: Electromagnetism, thermal physics, solid state and materials physics.

PH2301.title: PHYSICAL OPTICS
PH2301.description: This course aims to establish the basic principles of physical optics which form the foundation for many modern sciences and technologies. Wave properties, refraction and dispersion, interference, Michelson interferometer, Fraunhofer and Fresnel diffraction, resolution limit, Fourier transformation, holography; polarization, birefringence and wave plates, Fabry-Perot etalons, optical coatings, zone plates.

PH2601.title: INTRODUCTION TO LASERS
PH2601.description:
This course serves as an introduction to lasers and their working principles.
Quantum transitions in atoms, stimulated emission and amplification, rate equations, saturation, feedback, coherent optical oscillation, laser resonators, and various types of lasers.

PH3201.title: STATISTICAL MECHANICS I
PH3201.description:
This course introduces the postulates and key ideas in statistical mechanics, with applications to classical and quantal gases.

* Basic postulates, macrostates and microstates, distinguishable and indistinguishable particles, distribution functions
* Temperature, entropy and the probability of system configuration occurring, Boltzmann relation, canonical ensemble and partition function
* Gibb's entropy; Third law of thermodynamics; information theory; irreversible processes and arrow of time
* Density of states; heat capacity in black body radiation
* Ideal classical gas, Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution, rotational and vibrational heat
* Free electron gas, Fermi energy and distribution function, Pauli paramagnetism
* Electronic contribution to heat capacity
* Phonons as normal modes, contribution to heat capacity, Debye approximation; phonon gas, thermal conductivity of insulators
* Mean description of phase transitions - Weiss model of ferromagnetism, order-disorder transition

PH3399.title: PHYSICS LAB IIIB
PH3399.description: This course provides students in the Applied Physics Track with further advanced training in experimental physics covering a wide variety of topics: semiconductor physics, photonics, biophysics, and thin film growth.

PH3401.title: ATOMIC PHYSICS
PH3401.description:
This course discusses the origins of atomic spectra and shows the application of quantum mechanics in describing the interaction between electrons and nuclei in atoms. 
Hydrogen atom - central potential approximation, radial wavefunction, quantum numbers, energy levels and degeneracy; electron spin and total angular momentum; spin-orbit coupling and fine structure; Zeeman splitting. Helium atom - Coulomb repulsion and exchange; singlet-triplet splitting. Electronic configuration and periodic table; alkali metals; residual electrostatic interaction; LS-coupling scheme; Hund?s rules; hyperfine structure and isotope shift. Selection rules for electric dipole interaction. Zeeman and Stark effects. Inner shell transitions and x-ray spectra. Modern experiments in atomic physics.

PH3402.title: SOLID STATE PHYSICS I
PH3402.description:
This course discusses the electronic and magnetic properties of solids.
Metals - conductivity and heat capacity; density of states at Fermi level; nearly free electron model and band gaps. Distinction between metals, semiconductors and insulators.
Semiconductors - direct and indirect band gap (Si, Ge, GeAs); optical absorption, effective mass and holes; carrier concentration, law of mass action; impurity donors and acceptors; mobility and Hall effect; band gap measurements.
Magnetic susceptibility, Larmor diamagnetism, paramagnetism and Curie?s law; Pauli paramagnetism; magnetic ordering (ferromagnetism and anti-ferromagnetism) and Weiss molecular field theory; Curie-Weiss susceptibility.

PH3502.title: CHAOTIC DYNAMICAL SYSTEMS
PH3502.description:
This course introduces the ideas of determinism and randomness in the physical world.

* Introduction to phase plane, critical points and characterization (hyperbolic/elliptic) - free and damped oscillators, prey-predator models
* Simple extensions to three-dimensional phase space and beyond, e.g. rotation of rigid bodis, the Lorenz system
* Integrable and non-integrable systems, Poincare return maps
* Discrete dynamics - 1D and 2D maps; fixed points and stability; period doubling - shift map, logistic map
* Breakdown of order and chaos; sensitivity to initial conditions ("butterfly effect") and Lyapunov exponents; limit to predictability; strange attractors and fractal dimension - Kepler problem, Henon-Heiles system
* Stable and unstable manifolds, homoclinic and heteroclinic tangle, lobes and turnstile transport, particle motion in 2D incompressible fluid

PH4401.title: QUANTUM MECHANICS III
PH4401.description:
This course discusses quantum interactions between matter and electromagnetic fields.
Time-independent perturbation theory - non-degenerate and degenerate. Variational method, ground state energy and eigenfunction. Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
Hamiltonian in an electromagnetic field, vector potential, phase and Aharanov-Bohm effect. Dirac equation, spin, gyromagnetic ratio and antiparticles. Zeeman and Landau levels.
Transitions - two-state system, Rabi oscillations, Larmor precession, magnetic resonance; time-dependent perturbation theory, Fermi's golden rule, scattering and Born approximation; radiative transition transitions; electric dipole approximation, quantised electromagnetic field.
Quantum information - quantum cryptography, entanglement and teleportation; quantum computing.

PH4404.title: NANOSCALE PHYSICS
PH4404.description:
This course introduces the physical and transport properties in nanoscale systems.
Electron gas in 2D and multilayer systems. 
Quantum transport in 1D; magnetotunneling; quantum capacitance and conductance.
Quantum dots and artificial atoms; eigenenergies and eigenstates; single particle conductance; Coulomb blockade; Kondo effect; Aharanov-Bohm effect.

PHO330.title: LIGHTING FOR STUDIO AND LOCATION
PHO330.description: In this course, students will explore set ups and techniques that are used in editorial and commercial work. Through demonstrations and discussions on metering, exposure, and film types, students will learn how to produce the desired effects through exploration of a variety of lighting strategies using single, multiple, and mixed sources. As students become more comfortable with all the aspects of the studio and more advanced photographic equipment such as spot and flash meters, and high end digital backs, the class discussion will move on selective ways of using lighting techniques to enhance the certain moods, concepts, or contents of the photographs. The studio and location workshop will train students how to both create lighting and work with existing conditions. There will also be assignments and projects in which students will be able to further investigate their particular area of interest.

PHO370.title: DOCUMENTARY PROJECTS
PHO370.description: Documentary project is a powerful tool for communication and for fostering understanding and change.  This advanced level studio critique course aims to expand the boundaries of artistic, creative, and realistic perspective in documentary projects.  The course also stresses aesthetic, scholarly, and ethical considerations involved in representing other people and cultures. Discussion will address how photographers as well as multi media artists, such as Nan Goldin, Rineke Dijkstra, Philip-Lorca diCorcia, and Shirin Neshat, have embodied their meanings through cross-genre narrative techniques.  Topics will include developing concepts, approaching people, using available light, and creating a dynamic composition.  Through assignments and critiques, students will gain an awareness of the expressive possibilities of their surroundings.

PRO350.title: PRODUCT DESIGN IV
PRO350.description: Pervasive, Mobile and Wearable Computing is transforming the way people conduct business, take care of their health, entertain themselves, and more. Advances in computer technology allows for the integration and embedding of technology into many everyday household objects and devices. This course looks at the futuristic aspects of such devices/ products  both physical and digital, and the closing gap between the two  and encourages a human, experiential attitude towards interactive product design.

PRO360.title: ADVANCED DEVELOPMENT AND PROTOTYPING
PRO360.description: This course will allow the student to develop a portfolio of their individual work. The students develop 3  projects in specific and current areas of Product Design. This fast paced studio builds confidence in students to deal with different projects; create scenarios, conceptualize and build prototypes. This studio prepares them to the real world situation and showcases their abilities and their desires, enabling them to define their future career.

PS8001.title: DEFENCE SCIENCE
PS8001.description: This course introduces the role of mathematical and physical sciences in Defence Science.This course is Pass/Fail graded.

RE1004.title: ENGINEERING SCIENCE I
RE1004.description: Engineering Science I serves as an introductory course for all Renaissance students in year 1. This course covers topics in basic mathematics with emphasis on first- and second-order ordinary differential equations, basic physics with emphasis on electricity, magnetism, light and optics, and basic chemistry with more advanced discussions on the fundamental concepts and materials used in the earth, sustainability, life and natural cycles and environmental related problems. Through the sample questions/exercises provided in the course material, the students will have chances to pick up the fundamental principles related concepts into engineering science applications.

RE1005.title: POWER ENGINEERING
RE1005.description: The first part of this course aims to provide students with an understanding of the basic principles of electric power and machines. It covers the fundamentals of power systems, electromagnetism, transformers and rotating machines. The second part of this course aims to provide students with a good understanding of the fundamental principles of thermal-fluids sciences. It covers topics on fluid mechanics, temperature and ideal gases, laws of thermodynamics and mechanisms of heat and mass transfer. Applications of these concepts in solving simple engineering problems will also be covered.

RE1006.title: MATERIALS AND MANUFACTURING ENGINEERING
RE1006.description:
This course provides an essential foundation to subsequent courses in the curriculum. As well as providing fundamental description of the underlying material science concepts, it enables the student to appreciate how these factors relate to the development of mechanical properties, functional properties, as well as manufacturing processes. A pivotal objective in the course is environmental awareness and responsibility for material choice. 
Both the materials and manufacturing factors are drawn together by a thematic study of the i-PAD, as well as a hands-on session in a semiconductor laboratory.

RE2005.title: ENGINEERING SCIENCE II
RE2005.description: Engineering Science II serves as an introductory course for all Renaissance students in year 2. It aims to equip students with a firm foundation and superior problem-solving skills in the science of chemistry and biology. As an introductory course, it exposes the student to a wide spectrum of technical concepts. The topics include: redox processes,  electrochemistry, energy storage, transition metal chemistry of metal complexes, spectroscopy analytical chemistry , cell growth kinetics, bioreactor design, and bioprocess engineering, biomechanics, molecular recognition, systems physiology, spectroscopy and pharmacokinetics. Student will also be introduced to the relevant fundamentals of energy, biology and medicine, including applications such as fuel cells, regenerative medicine, biosensors and artificial organ devices.

RE2006.title: ENGINEERING COMPUTATION
RE2006.description:
This course aims at developing students? understanding of the CPU of a computer, how it functions and how to program a computer in order to solve problems. Students are introduced to the hardware architecture of the CPU, the timing of different types of signals that control the functioning of the CPU. They are taught how to program a CPU using assembly language that resembles very closely the codes that are executed by the CPU. They learn how to connect different peripheral devices so that the CPU can interact with the external world. Different types of memories and how to interface them are also introduced.

Further, this course also aims to develop students? understanding of the fundamental concepts, implementations and applications associated with data structures in computing such as arrays, stacks, queues and linked lists and to use such data structures to solve real world problems. Abstract data types and dynamic memory allocation will also be covered.

RE2007.title: DESIGN AND SYSTEMS ENGINEERING
RE2007.description: The course spans 39 hours of which 26 hrs are devoted to seminars and 13 hours to in-class discussions and assignments. The course contents include and introduction to systems engineering, systems design, systems life-cycle, systems test and evaluation, systems integration, the management of implementation of systems, needs and product specifications, collaborative engineering, design for excellence (DFX), requirement management and mass customization, axiomatic design and intelligent systems. A term project to reinforce learning of the principles and practice of design and systems engineering is mandatory.

RE2008.title: INTEGRATED DESIGN PROJECT
RE2008.description: This course covers topics in applied computer, mechanical, electronic, civil, environmental and chemical engineering/science as well as business development in the integrated engineering design phase. The students are expected to apply their computer design and research skills to incorporate with their innovative and critical analytical skills to ensure their engineering prototype functionable and marketable without neglecting the aesthetic part of the product. Throughout the project, literature research, computer aided designs and critical discussion are essential.

RE8004.title: THE CHANGING GLOBAL ECONOMY
RE8004.description:
This course introduces students to the current issues in the world economy. These include economic growth, stagnation, volatility, government policy, international cooperation. As well as inculcating factual knowledge it gives students a sound background in macroeconomic and trade theory. It also makes them aware of the unprecedented challenges that will be faced by consumers, businesses and governments in the new global economy.

The course proceeds in thirteen weekly sessions (39 hours in all) from a study of the market economy to the national income, the circular flow, total demand, money and banking and international economics. It will also include a discussion of new economic problems such as world health outcomes and the ageing population. The course includes six seminars in which students give presentations on an independent (group) research project and four discussion sessions in which the students ensure that they have a good understanding of the material covered in lectures and in the textbook.
programmes: General Education in Art, Humanities and Social Sciences

RE8005.title: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT
RE8005.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with a broad understanding of the key financial principles, concepts and analytical tools. This is an introductory course in finance. Topics include the time value of money, interest rates, bond and stock valuation, capital budgeting, risk and return, cost of capital, market efficiency, corporate financing and payout policy, and an introduction to options.

SP0003.title: THE GREAT IDEAS
SP0003.description: This course is about great ideas. 'Great ideas' in this context refers to those ideas that have had a significant and enduring impact on academic, artistic, political, socioeconomic, and scientific developments in our time or that they shine new light on conventions and cause a paradigm shift in sensibility and thought. They are ideas that have had a notable influence on how people think of themselves, of other people, and about the world. They are ideas that provoke hearty endorsement. They are also ideas that incite vehement objection. The works explored in this course are only part of what can be considered a canon of ideas that have been produced by generations of remarkable activists, intellectuals, philosophers, and scientists who, echoing Socrates, considered the unexamined life not worth living. It is hoped nonetheless that these albeit limited number of ideas will at the least convey the excitement of intellectual pursuits, and move readers of this course to critically reflect on their lives and times. Organizationally, the course will explore ideas hailing from a wide array of disciplines. Depending on the course instructor, new themes and readings may be included for discussion.
programmes: Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering And Economics Year 1
Electrical & Electronic Engineering And Economics Year 1
Information Engineering & Media And Economics Year 1

SP0005.title: QUANTITATIVE REASONING
SP0005.description:
This course consists of several parts.

1.	Introduction

This part introduces the fundamental ideas and challenges in problem solving and decision making, with an emphasis on the roles of qualitative reasoning and quantitative reasoning. 

2.	Quantitative Reasoning with Complexity

This part introduces students to the problem-solving and decision making process and the basic ideas and techniques in optimization. 

3.	Quantitative Reasoning with Uncertainty and Risk

This part studies the basic concepts and techniques in decision analysis. We will review the basics in probability and statistics and then introduce students to the basic ideas and techniques in decision analysis including utility theory.

4.	Quantitative Reasoning with Conflict and Competition

This part introduces students to decision making with conflict and competitive, and the basic concepts and techniques in negotiation and game theories.  

5.	Quantitative Reasoning in our Daily Life

The objective of this part is to apply quantitative reasoning to the solution of real-life decision problems.
programmes: Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering And Economics Year 1
Electrical & Electronic Engineering And Economics Year 1
Information Engineering & Media And Economics Year 1

SS0101.title: SINGAPORE SPORT IN THE 21ST CENTURY
SS0101.description: The process of change is just as apparent in sport as it is in any field of human endeavour. Sport in Singapore is a significant medium for social development that must also be seen to make contributions to the economy, to education, to social activity and to the creation of a national and an international identity. Government initiatives at the turn of the century are gradually being crystallised into meaningful actions affecting the wider population. Active participation in sport is encouraged and the status of sport as a potential career path is emerging more strongly.  Singapore has been recognised as a successful host of an increasing number of events, yet still requires affirmation of its competitive standards at international levels. This course will critically examine the nature and scope of sport related issues that have evolved during the 21st Century.

SS0201.title: ETHICAL ISSUES IN SPORT
SS0201.description: Sport is a socially significant activity for many individuals.  Moreover, the sports industry is global, saturates the media, influences young people and is a massive arm of the entertainment industry which generates billions of dollars each year.  The influence that such a massive industry plays on society generates a unique set of ethical issues.  This course will critically examine a number of the ethical issues surrounding the role of sport in society and ask the student to question and analyse the role of the sport in today?s world.

SS1004.title: INTRODUCTION TO GROWTH & MOTOR DEVELOPMENT
SS1004.description: This course is designed for the understanding of physical growth and motor development, particularly during childhood and adolescence. The impact of age-related changes, individual and sex-differences, maturity-associated variation on physical growth and motor development will be covered.

SS1005.title: HEALTH & WELLNESS I
SS1005.description:
Health & Wellness
	Heath Education, Prevention & Promotion
	Substance Abuse/Smoking
	Cancer/STDs & AIDS
	Nutritional Concerns
	Weight Management 
	Body Image Disorders
	Stress Management

SS1006.title: EXERCISE & SPORT PHYSIOLOGY I
SS1006.description: A lecture/demonstration laboratory course is designed as a foundation course for the study of exercise physiology. Emphasis will be placed on; the energy systems that fuel muscular work, muscle fiber types, aerobic and anaerobic performance and training adaptations, blood lactate after exercise and maximal oxygen uptake. The importance of proper fluid management and aspects of thermoregulation during exercise in the local tropical environment will also be emphasised.

SS2001.title: EXERCISE & SPORT PSYCHOLOGY 1
SS2001.description: This focus of this module is on the social and psychological aspects of sport and exercise. Topics covered include personality, motivation, stress and coping, aggression, moral development, team building and cohesion, competition, and leadership. Emphasis will be on the role of sport psychology in influencing participants' cognition, emotion, and behaviour in physical activity and sport settings.

SS2006.title: RESEARCH METHODS & DESIGN IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY & SPORT
SS2006.description: This course provides students with a foundation from which to critically examine quantitative and qualitative research designs and strategies.  Every effort will be made to place such designs and strategies and their applications in basic or pure and applied settings of physical education and sport.  Specifically, the module introduces the student to: the nature of the research process, the use of literature, the definition and evaluation of a research problem, hypothesis formation, scientific investigation and methods, types of research available and abstract and report writing.

SS2007.title: SPORT INJURIES I
SS2007.description: This module is designed to provide students with fundamental knowledge and skills to prevent and manage sports injuries. The module covers background knowledge in dealing with sports injuries from first aid care to rehabilitation.

SS3102.title: EXERCISE & SPORT PHYSIOLOGY III
SS3102.description: A lecture/laboratory course is designed to provide a basic framework that will aid the third year students in acquiring knowledge and technical laboratory skills pertinent to exercise physiology.  The laboratory techniques and knowledge will help students to understand the demands of training on the body and will enable them to prescribe exercise or training for optimal health and elite performance. Emphasis will be placed on the energy contribution during high intensity exercise, prediction of performance in endurance events, lactate threshold/ventilatory thresholds and maximal oxygen uptake. The importance of body composition and the different assessment modes will also be emphasised.

SS3104.title: HEALTH & WELLNESS II
SS3104.description:
The course addresses current trends in health and wellness.
This could include a critical analysis of current problems and trends in basic health education that contribute to healthful living in community, home and school.

SS3202.title: SPORT BIOMECHANICS III
SS3202.description: This course will focus on the quantitative analysis of human movement.  Participants will learn how to design a quantitative analysis, collect, analyse and interpret data obtained from the equipment associated with the measurement technique.  From the analysis work of this course, participants will be expected to examine the relationship between performance measure and human motor system.  Participants will have the opportunity to explore the underlying processes that is involved in the production of this human movement.  The course will consist of theory and applied field work.

SS3302.title: EXERCISE & SPORT PSYCHOLOGY III
SS3302.description: The focus of this course is on theory, research and practices in sport and exercise psychology. This course includes an overview of varied psychology topics (e.g., individual differences/personality, social influence and group dynamics, diversity issues, and applied psychological skills). The main focus is to understand major theories and research as well as applying those theories and research findings to diverse sport and exercise settings. In addition, the development and evaluation of basic psychological skills training programmes will be introduced.

SS3402.title: MOTOR LEARNING & CONTROL III
SS3402.description: The purpose of this course is to examine the concepts associated with human movement from neuromuscular basis. The course covers important structures involved in motor control from anatomical, neurophysiological, and biomechanical perspectives, and addresses how they interact to control various body parts.

SS3605.title: MANAGEMENT OF SPORT ORGANIZATIONS
SS3605.description: This course uses the essential topics and concepts of organisational theory to understand the underlying objectives and perspectives of managing sport organisations.  Students will develop from the course broad understanding of the nature of sport organisations, leadership, planning, problem solving and decision making and issues in managing sport organisations.

SS3606.title: FINANCE & BUSINESS IN SPORT
SS3606.description: This course develops in the student understanding of important financial concepts and systems.  Sources of sport funding are explored and how would sport organisation utilise such financial resources.  Fundamental principles of financial analysis, capital structuring and financial management are covered to develop better understanding of financial and business issues related to sport.

SS4401.title: LIFESPAN MOTOR DEVELOPMENT
SS4401.description: This course focuses on human motor development including fundamental motor pattern characteristics, human growth, perceptual motor development and fitness development across the lifespan with emphasis on adults and seniors. Socio-cultural influences on motor development will also be discussed. Theories and models of motor development also feature in this course.

SS4601.title: LEISURE & RECREATION MANAGEMENT
SS4601.description: The course explores the concept of leisure and recreation in historical and social perspectives.  What are some of the current needs and issues of leisure and recreation?  How are leisure and recreation planning and programming done?  What are the areas in leisure and recreation?  Who are important stakeholders in any leisure and recreation planning and delivery?  Students will undertake independent study of their leisure and recreation environment and suggest strategies to effectively meet the needs and demands of such activities.

SS9001.title: CONDITIONING FOR PHYSICAL FITNESS
SS9001.description:
Knowledge of aspects related to physical conditioning and weight training will be essential for students who plan to work in the 
fitness industry. The practical course on conditioning for physical fitness will equip our students with theoretical and practical skills to meet the needs of potential clients in fitness gyms and resorts. The course is 36 hours' duration.

SS9002.title: PRINCIPLES OF STRENGTH TRAINING
SS9002.description:
This module is structured to provide a concept and practice-based understanding of muscular fitness and conditioning on the following aspects:

1.	Components of muscular fitness
2.	Principles of muscular exercise and fitness
a.	Muscular exercise & fitness for health and sports performance
b.	Principles of strength training and muscular fitness 
3.	Muscular fitness training
a.	Types of resistance/strength training
b.	Familiarisation to equipment for strength training
c.	Strength training programmes
d.	Designing a personal muscular fitness programme
e.	Posture and lower back strength
f.	Exercise safety and injury prevention
4.	Monitoring and assessment of muscular fitness

SS9101.title: BADMINTON
SS9101.description: The course aims to provide students with opportunities to acquire the knowledge, understanding and experience necessary to develop an appreciation of, and play, the sport of badminton. Students will be taught the essential skills necessary to play the sport.

SS9102.title: TENNIS
SS9102.description: This 36-hour course aims to impart the knowledge and competencies essential to having an informed understanding and appreciation of tennis. Students will be introduced to the basic skills necessary to play the game.

SS9103.title: SQUASH
SS9103.description: This course is designed to impart basic squash skills and knowledge of the game of squash to players at an introductory stage leading into intermediate levels. The emphasis of the course is on providing ample opportunities to play the game at a recreational as well as a competitive level. Also under consideration are the respective roles of player, referee and coach in creating a meaningful experience.

SS9104.title: BASKETBALL
SS9104.description: This course is designed to provide students with the basic skills and knowledge to play and enjoy recreational basketball. Students will be taught on basic fundamental skills, rule/terminology, officiating, team offense/defense, and situational strategies.

SS9105.title: VOLLEYBALL
SS9105.description:
1.	To provide knowledge, understanding, and appreciation to the game of volleyball.
2.	To develop satisfactory competency in basic skills such as body posture, forearm pass, serve and serve reception, overhead pass, attack, block, and game situational strategies. 
3.	To provide contents and methods required to teach volleyball at an introductory level. 
4.	To provide experience in game situations and officiating the game.
5.	To be familiar with offensive and defensive strategies and able to execute them in game situations
6.	To provide understanding of the teaching/coaching techniques 
7.	To lay a foundation for more advanced study/coaching in volleyball.

SS9106.title: NETBALL
SS9106.description: The course is designed to impart basic netball skills and knowledge. Participants will be given the opportunity to develop the basic footwork and ball skills, goal shooting skills, and study the principles of attacking/defending, as well as the application of these skills and game concepts/tactics in game play.

SS9107.title: TABLE TENNIS
SS9107.description:
?	Introduction to the history, rules, and current trends in table tennis
?	Concepts of grips, various racket surface(rubbers) and footwork 
?	Essential technical skills of table tennis - forehand and backhand drives, push, chops  and service of various spins (top spin, under spin and side spin)
?	Specialty shots and styles of play
?	Singles and doubles strategies
?	Different competition formats
?	Use of software and video

SS9201.title: GOLF
SS9201.description: Golf is a sport closely associated with country club resorts. Understanding the game of golf can assist students to be familiar with how this game is played at such facilities, and be in a better position to further develop their knowledge and skills associated with either working in such facilities or in employment opportunities where one's playing experience in golf is an advantage. The course is 36 hours' duration.

SS9202.title: SOCCER
SS9202.description: The 36-hour course aims to develop basic skills in soccer, and to provide an understanding and appreciation of the sport through an experiential process. Students will be introduced to the historical development and current trends in soccer, the technical aspects of soccer, strategies and tactics employed in the sport, and competition formats.

SS9203.title: HOCKEY
SS9203.description: Hockey as a game may seem ?strange and unfamiliar ?but actually it has many similarities to other sports. This course will enable students to learn the game of hockey in a fun manner. It pays particular attention to safety and will enable participants to enjoy the skills in a simple yet enjoyable manner. By the end of the course participants will be more aware of field hockey as a sport which can be enjoyed by all ages and all levels of ability.

SS9204.title: FLOORBALL
SS9204.description: Floorball is a young and fast growing game in Singapore and the world. The game is adapted from Ice Hockey. The game has grown quickly in Singapore as it is fast paced (high intensity), safe (using plastic based equipment) and easy to pick up. This course will enable students to learn the game of floorball in a fun and safe environment through a game centered approach. By the end of the course, the students will be able to appreciate and enjoy playing the game.

SS9205.title: RUGBY
SS9205.description: This course aims to develop knowledge, understanding and playing competency in the various forms of rugby football namely, tag rugby, touch rugby and contact rugby. The basic techniques, tactics and strategies will be learnt and applied in practice and match situations and analysed from theoretical, practical and biomechanical perspectives.

SS9302.title: DANCESPORT
SS9302.description: This course is structured to provide a concept (understanding different dance elements and terminology) and practice-based understanding of dance, specifically jazz and dance sport. Basic movement activities including locomotor movements, use of space, use of dynamics and original dance patterns. Social dances include Samba, Waltz and Cha-cha.

SS9303.title: INTRODUCTION TO HIP-HOP AND ITS DANCES
SS9303.description: How many times have you wondered- what exactly is Hip-Hop? Over this course, learners will be exposed to how the Hip-Hop culture we know of today, born in the mid-1970s in an impoverished section of New York City, found its way to the mass media and mainstream population and evolved into a multi-million dollar industry. Emphasis will be placed on learning about roots of Hip-Hop, particularly its dances. Participants will learn to dance to the rhythm of music and be introduced to some common moves popularized by prominent dance pioneers.

SS9401.title: AQUATICS
SS9401.description:
The course aims to develop stroke competencies and techniques in swimming. Participants will be expected to practice, acquire and finally, demonstrate correct and efficient technique in a least three out of the four swimming strokes (frontcrawl, breaststroke, backstroke and butterfly).

Related activities will also be introduced in the course:
	Basic Personal Survival and Life Saving Techniques
	Fundamentals of Water Polo
	Canoe Polo Basics
	Organising Swimming / Water Sports Events

VIS350.title: GRAPHIC DESIGN IV
VIS350.description: In preparation for the fourth year and as a bridge between the rigidity of the Graphic Design course series and the flexibility of the Final Year Project, this holistic studio provides students the opportunity to develop a personal direction and voice. Students explore, experiment and innovate within a research-based, highly conceptual environment in the design of interdisciplinary projects proposed by the instructor.

VIS380.title: PRODUCTION FOR GRAPHIC DESIGNERS
VIS380.description: This course covers materials related to the actual production of design materials that are often overlooked during education and usually learned by experience. Image reproduction, press-checks, color specifications and proofing, trapping procedures, file preparation, paper selections and binding and finishing techniques will all be explored. At the end of this course, students will gain the basic production knowledge.
